Award.AwardTitle: A Study of Networked Infrastructures that Supply Water for Both Shipping and Municipal Use

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Introduction

This postdoctoral fellowship will support research on water infrastructure in Panama; it focuses specifically on the networked infrastructures that supplies water for both shipping and municipal use. The project has three phases focusing respectively on installation, maintenance, and use. Each phase is structured in terms of a core question. The first phase asks how the water management infrastructure that links the canal with the two cities at its endpoints, Panama and Colon, shaped system development and regional water distribution problems. It will be answered through historical research at archives in the US and Panama. The second asks how expectations and practices of infrastructure maintenance compare between the two institutions that manage water in the study region. This question will be answered through participant observation and interviews with work crews and administrators at both water management institutions. The third asks how urban water users perceive delivery problems and develop household strategies to cope with them. This question will be answered through semi-structured interviews and participant observation in urban Panama.

Intellectual Merit

The project will advance scholarship in three areas. It will merge STS scholarship on infrastructure and political ecology in a novel manner resulting in a new, powerful framework that will benefit both fields. It will utilize the new framework to advance scholarship in the emerging Science and Technology Studies subfield, Water Studies. Finally, it will provide evidence to better theorize how infrastructure functions across geographical and cultural differences, illuminating how these systems work when irregular maintenance and service interruption are a part of everyday life.

Potential Broader Impacts

Infrastructures have become visible sites of economic anxiety, political struggle, and ecological crisis in recent years. Communities worldwide face problems of service delivery associated with aging infrastructure and state budgetary shortfalls. The research will generate new knowledge about technology, society, and ecology under these conditions that is relevant to engineers, planners, and administrators who seek to design and manage socio-technical systems in more culturally appropriate, equitable, and sustainable ways. The project will illuminate how urban water problems are produced and might be ameliorated. Findings will be disseminated to multiple audiences through academic conferences, publications in peer-reviewed journals, public workshops, and the training of engineering students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the goals of the project was to advance broader understanding of the multiscale social, technical, and political dimensions of water management through research on the Panama Canal as it relates to networked infrastructures, particularly municipal water systems. The major outcomes of the project that represent the successful achievement of this goal included: the publication of scholarly work (a book, peer-reviewed journal articles, and book chapters) and the public presentation of research findings detailing how the social, technical, and political dimensions of shipping and municipal water infrastructures in Panama have been intertwined to establish a complex sociotechnical system.

Another project goal was the integration of scholarship in the field of science, technology, and society (STS) with anthropology and geography scholarship on society-environment relations in order to better understand relationships between networked infrastructures and water distribution within the context of globalization. Major outcomes of the project that represent the successful achievement of this goal included: interdisciplinary publications, presentations, and other forms of dissemination using the case of the Panama Canal to support the broader argument that managed water systems must be understood not simply as technical projects but social, political, and ecological endeavors.

The field of STS has been growing and an increasingly important subfield in STS is water studies, which has important practical and policy implications for the design and management of engineered infrastructures. An important outcome of the project was to advance this subfield of STS by developing theory and adding a substantial, empirical analysis of the Panama Canal to the body of knowledge. 

The role that geography and cultural context play in the design and operation of engineered infrastructures is a topic that requires more theoretical development. An important outcome of this project was to advance theory about the geographical and cultural context of infrastructure by conducting and publishing research on the global emergence and development of the infrastructure concept and the specific forms that infrastructure has taken in the Panamanian context.

In terms of broader impacts, the project was designed to generate and disseminate knowledge about water management and infrastructure relevant to engineers, planners, and administrators. That goal was achieved through the communication of data in the form of publications and presentations oriented toward relevant professionals and the public in the United States and Panama. The investigators also communicated directly with Panamanian and international engineers, planners, and administrators about the research at professional conferences and individual meetings. In Panama, investigators met with a variety of international development and water utility professionals involved in water management. Finally, the goal was achieved through the publication of peer-reviewed and accessible publications in English and Spanish.
